awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Understanding and Modeling the Trade-Offs in Data Centers for Next-Generation Sustainable Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The success of cloud computing as a business model has led to several commercial cloud services for storage, data mining and searching, and multimedia content delivery. As cloud services penetrate emerging markets   -- notably the smart-phone market  --  conventional utility services such as television are becoming ?cloudized.?   

As the economy becomes more dependent on the efficient operation of cloud data centers (DCs), there?s an increasingly urgent need to design ?green? and energy-adaptive management software that optimizes the operation of a geographically distributed set of data centers under varying workload and energy conditions.

Cyber-physical, proactive and predictive decision making is essential for a DC operating system that efficiently predicts, e.g., the workload and the power consumption when running multiple jobs on the same server and makes decisions, e.g., for redistributing the servicing virtual machines  among varying number of available DCs, electricity cost, percentage of renewable energy supply and capacity of energy storage. 

This project is addressing the scientific and engineering challenges involved in decision making of such DC management arising from an array of complicating factors -- e.g., server heterogeneity, cyber-physical interactions between DCs and their environment, varying  workload and  electricity pricing -- and trade-offs  -- e.g., energy-delay, time-accuracy, and cooling-computing . The project is developing a Green cyber-physical Data Center Simulator, GDCSim, for studying the tradeoffs in practical scenarios with several complicating factors.  

Project aims to enable a more sustainable cloud computing and to train engineers for a greener economy.  The project findings are available through ASU-IMPACT lab?s website (http://impact.asu.edu/).

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to design management software that optimizes the operation of a geographically distributed set of data centers, under dynamic workload and energy conditions. The research was aimed at addressing various tradeoffs in managing dynamic workload and power in data centers. The aim was to consider various aspects of the data center including workload (such as internet and high-performance computing) , operational cost in terms of energy, cooling efficiency, renewable energy harvesting, and energy storage. The trade-offs that were considered in the course of the research included latency-energy tradeoff, where interference effect of co-hosted applications were included in the formulation, accuracy-depth trade-off of workload prediction of internet data centers, cooling-computing energy trade-off of workload consolidation, and capacity-leakage trade-off of energy storage devices. The primary challenge at the individual data center level was to characterize the cyber-physical interactions of among equipment within each data center such as equipment thermal interferences and of the data center with its environment such as data center carbon footprint. The outcomes of the interactions at the individual data center level in terms of energy cost, latency, harvested energy, and carbon footprint, affected the operation of the geo-distributed data center network. Such inter-relations were analyzed through mathematical formulations and grounded with practical experimentations using software tools such as GDCSim and hardware testbeds such as BlueTool.

The principal outcomes of the project include the following:

a) Cyber-physical workload distribution in internet datacenters: The project resulted in a two-tier Internet data center management scheme TACOMA (Fig 1.), which is a combination for thermal aware server provisioning (TASP) in one tier and thermal aware workload distribution (TAWD) in the provisioned servers in the second layer. Combined with different temporal job scheduling strategies TASP and TAWD variants can lead to a maximum of 40% energy savings as compared to contemporary techniques.

b) Workload prediction and balancing with renewable generation in Internet data center:  The principal outcome was a dynamic Geographical Load Balancing and energy buffering management (GLB) scheme which (i) shifts workload (particularly peak workload demand) toward Data centers that offer low utility rate or green energy at a time, and (ii) banks excess green and low-cost energy to shift peak workload demand away from high utility rate. Such a scheme needs to be aware of the workload intensity and the available renewable power of the cloud in future (over a relatively long prediction window such as a day). The performance of the online GLB solution when using time-series based prediction techniques (e.g., ARIMA ) for the workload and the renewable power (i.e., solar and wind) we studied. The results of the simulation study using realistic traces highlight that GLB with and without prediction error is effective in reducing average energy cost and increasing sustainability of data centers. GLB is shown to be significantly effective in shaving peak power draw from the grid (e.g., reducing peak power upto 100).

c) Workload management framework for geographically distributed data centers: This resulted in Dynamic Application Hosting Management (DAHM) architecture that achieves cost-efficient application hosting by taking into account: (i) the spatio-temporal variation of energy cost, (ii) the data center computing and cooling energy efficiency, (iii) the live migration cost, and (iv) any SLA violations due to migration overhead or network delay. Using DAHM can potentially result in 33% cost savings for application hosting in a geo-distributed data center setting.

d) Workload distribution across datacenters for joint optimization of electricity cost and carbon footprint: This resulted in an online algorithm, called OnlineCC, for minimizing the operational cost while satisfying the carbon footprint reduction target of a set of geo-distributed data centers. OnlineCC makes use of Lyapunov optimization technique while operating without long-term future information, making it attractive in the presence of uncertainties associated with data center information e.g., input workload. OnlineCC achieves a near optimal operational cost (electricity cost) compared to the optimal algorithm with future information, while bounding the potential violation of carbon footprint target, depending on the Lyapunov control parameter, namely V. We also give a heuristic for finding V which significantly shortens the search space to adjust its value. Experimental results show that OnlineCC reduces cost by more than 18% compared to a prediction-based online solution while resulting in equal or smaller carbon footprint.

Results from this project were published in several conference and journal articles as well as book chapters. Also several US patent applications were filed and at least one has been granted. Further, several students recevied advanced education.

In addition to the above-mentioned outcomes, we have also applied the theories proposed to other domains such as co-operative computing in mobile phones in a mobile crowds sensing architecture. We have proposed ContextAiDe, an architecture for programming, distributed task execution and optimization of context and operational overheads to facilitate real time mobile crowd sensing applications.
